That support has seen a litany of disastrous results for successive US administration's, from the Clintons, Bush, Obama and now Trump. The biggest failure in the Syrian conflict is political will to be able to refrain from Israeli fears the complex strain of decades long villification of Syrian soveriegnty and the very crux of the Middle East problem, Syria like Iran, Iraq, Libya all over the decades of strife and conflict sought too Nationalise there banking system and there vast oil resources, effectively free from the influence of Western Power and Israel's International Banking systems. That with the percieved threat of an economy that can support science, technology and massive arms build up is the real reason why Syria can not rise from the ashes, border clashes between Kurdish population by Turkish military, massive oil reserves and Russian military placement, makes the Syrian problem vastly complex. Yet there is a solution and Syria, Russia, Turkey, Israel can do it because the world economy needs this part of the world stable let the Russian and Turkish economy embrace Syria's potential, stop Israeli meddling and let Trump organise trade on a scale unprecedented for the American economy. The politics do not have to align both Turkey and Russia have stable robust economies, they are testament to progressive stable political systems, the West needs to expand its global trade and interact with the same aspirations rebuild the world economy and rebuild nations, demilitarisation can occur with economic recovery.   Trump can foresee the necessity of political solutions not military intervention, Russia is as much a global partner in solving the crisis. text:
Thank you, Mr Secretary General, your excellencies, ladies and gentleman, and distinguished guests. I‚Äôm honored to be here today, I stand before you not as an expert but as a concerned citizen, one of the 400,000 people who marched in the streets of New York on Sunday, and the billions of others around the world who want to solve our climate crisis.
As an actor I pretend for a living. I play fictitious characters often solving fictitious problems.
I believe humankind has looked at climate change in that same way: as if it were a fiction, happening to someone else‚Äôs planet, as if pretending that climate change wasn‚Äôt real would somehow make it go away.

But I think we know better than that. Every week, we‚Äôre seeing new and undeniable climate events, evidence that accelerated climate change is here now.¬†We know that droughts are intensifying, our oceans are warming and acidifying, with methane plumes rising up from beneath the ocean floor. We are seeing extreme weather events, increased temperatures, and the West Antarctic and Greenland ice-sheets melting at unprecedented rates, decades ahead of scientific projections.
None of this is rhetoric, and none of it is hysteria. It is fact. The scientific community knows it, Industry and governments know it, even the United States military knows it. The chief of the US navy‚Äôs Pacific command, admiral Samuel Locklear, recently said that climate change is our single greatest security threat.
My Friends, this body ‚Äì perhaps more than any other gathering in human history ‚Äì now faces that difficult task. You can make history ... or be vilified by it.

To be clear, this is not about just telling people to change their light bulbs or to buy a hybrid car. This disaster has grown BEYOND the choices that individuals make. This is now about our industries, and governments around the world taking decisive, large-scale action.
I am not a scientist, but I don‚Äôt need to be. Because the world‚Äôs scientific community has spoken, and they have given us our prognosis, if we do not act together, we will surely perish.
Now is our moment for action.
We need to put a pricetag on carbon emissions, and eliminate government subsidies for coal, gas, and oil companies. We need to end the free ride that industrial polluters have been given in the name of a free-market economy, they don‚Äôt deserve our tax dollars, they deserve our scrutiny. For the economy itself will die if our ecosystems collapse.
author: Samyak Jain

What a twit. He barely graduated high school, and he's going to tell you what to believe by doing what he does best....when paid, that is.....learn lines written by someone else....and then repeat them. 
There is no irrefutable science behind climate change. The scientists who say that humans cause climate change are all on grants from  governments. It is very much in their interest to say they need to study climate change.....they need the money. Studying climate change is not going to change the climate, but it does mean they get paid. Seven thousand years ago the Northern Hemisphere....Canada/Iceland/Greenland etc were covered by a sheet of ice 3 miles thick....and it melted due to atmospheric change....in other words the weather got warmer...a lot warmer...and it was not due to dinosaurs driving  around in gasoline powered vehicles etc etc etc.  Leonardo DiCaprio is a pretty little actor who can learn lines written by someone else and look good saying them..He has a minimal education consisting of attending Seeds Elementary School and then on to John Marshall High School. text:
Thank you, Mr. Secretary-General, your excellencies, ladies and gentleman, and distinguished guests. I‚Äôm honored to be here today, I stand before you not as an expert but as a concerned citizen, one of the 400,000 people who marched in the streets of New York on Sunday, and the billions of others around the world who want to solve our climate crisis.
As an actor I pretend for a living. I play fictitious characters often solving fictitious problems.
I believe mankind has looked at climate change in that same way: as if it were a fiction, as if pretending that climate change wasn‚Äôt real would somehow make it go away.
But I think we know better than that. Every week , we‚Äôre seeing new and undeniable climate events, evidence that accelerated climate change is here right now. Droughts are intensifying, our oceans are acidifying, with methane plumes rising up from the ocean floor. We are seeing extreme weather events, and the West Antarctic and Greenland ice-sheets melting at unprecedented rates, decades ahead of scientific projections.
None of this is rhetoric, and none of it is hysteria. It is fact. The scientific community knows it, industry knows it, governments know it, even the United States military knows it. The Chief of the U.S. Navy‚Äôs Pacific Command, Admiral Samuel Locklear, recently said that climate change is our single greatest security threat.
My Friends, this body ‚Äì perhaps more than any other gathering in human history ‚Äì now faces this difficult, but achievable task. You can make history‚Ä¶ or be vilified by it.
To be clear, this is not about telling people to change their light bulbs or buy a hybrid car. This disaster has grown BEYOND the choices that individuals make. This is now about our industries, and governments around the world taking decisive, large-scale action.
Now must be our moment for action.
We need to put a pricetag on carbon emissions, and eliminate government subsidies for oil, coal and gas companies. We need to end the free ride that industrial polluters have been given in the name of a free-market economy, they do not deserve our tax dollars, they deserve our scrutiny. For the economy itself will die if our eco-systems collapse.
The good news is that renewable energy is not only achievable but good economic policy.
This is not a partisan debate; it is a human one. Clean air and a livable climate are inalienable human rights. And solving this crisis is not a question of politics, it is a question of our own survival.
This is the most urgent of times, and the most urgent of messages.
Honored delegates, leaders of the world, I pretend for a living. But you do not.
The people made their voices heard on Sunday around the world and the momentum will not stop. But now it is YOUR turn, the time to answer humankind‚Äôs greatest challenge is now.
We beg of you to face it with courage. And honesty. Thank you.

text: LOL...Decrapio does not know the science. When he was filming here in western Canada in the middle of winter he told the whole world that he experienced global warming first hand when the temperature rose from well below zero degrees to well above zero in a matter of minutes brought on by strong westerly winds. He called the winds, "Chinook" winds and he told the whole world that the locals were "terrified" of the Chinook winds...lol..well...hmmmm...I have lived in the area of where he was filming for almost 60 years and I am very familiar with the Chinook winds so i will tell "the whole world" the truth about them.  The word "Chinook" is a native Canadian word first introduced hundreds of years ago by the local natives and I mean the natives that came here before the white man...ya...those natives. Chinook winds are perfectly natural and have been happening for centuries if not longer and have nothing to do with global warming and I can assure you, no one in their right mind (so that excludes all climate change alarmists) is afraid of the Chinook winds....no one. Who the hell wouldn't appreciate a nice warm breeze blowing through the area to melt all the snow and warm you up for a short period until winter blasts back again, time and time again until spring finally rolls around. We love the Chinook winds around here...we all do. The Chinook winds occur when warm air from the Pacific Ocean blows over the Rocky Mountains and displaces the ambient cold air increasing the outside temperature by several degrees in a very short period of time and there is a very nice chinook arch over the mountains when this happens. Ask any local if they like to see the chinook arch over the mountains and I can assure you they will smile and say yes, bring on the chinook winds...lol..Decrapio..OMG...would you really listen to someone who has absolutely no clue about the science or the facts and this one instance sealed the deal for me on Decrapios knowledge of the science or lack there of. I mean, he can talk all he wants about any other scientific explaination and I might believe him except when I live in the area he is talking about (on another interview, not this one) I realize he has no clue. Are you guys seriously going to believe anything he says knowing he is THAT misinformed about whet a Chinook wind is.....?????

text: +Kudi Because Animal Production creates THREE TIMES more CO2 than burning Fossil Fuel.
author: Sergei Romanoff

text: +Kudi Getting rid of animals is a lot harder
author: Trey K

text: ¬†@Trey K¬†¬†Reducing consumption of animal products is easier and more relastic than to switch within a relatively short time frame of a few year to alternative energie sources
author: Kudi

text:
¬†@Kudi¬†¬†CO2 actually has a longer lasting impact than Methane, however. Methane's half life is only about 10 years, whereas CO2 is over 100. Yes, both are important, but this new idea that methane is a bigger problem is simply false. CO2 is still the driver in long term climate change, Methane is accelerating it.

"Reducing consumption of animal products is easier and more relastic than to switch within a relatively short time frame of a few year to alternative energie sources"

I disagree. Billions of people are starving because of lack of food. Cutting CO2 is very easy, we already have many alternates that the governments are refusing to take advantage of.
author: Trey K

text: ¬†@Trey K¬†¬†The man made reasons for why hunger and starvation still exist are various, from food price increases due to unresponsible financial speculations with food to the purposeful economic degeneration of poorer countries by institutions such as the IMF and the World Bank. However, since up to 50% of all crops are fed to animals, and often are exported from third world countries (most of the time with support the local goverment), to feed the animals of western nations so the demand in animal products can be met, reducing animal products would in fact would ease the problem of hunger (as well as climate change). Most poor people from third world countries, most of the time cannot¬†afford¬†meat or other animal products, their¬†diets are mostly stapled around foods such as rice, vegetables, grains and fruits.
author: Kudi

text: ¬†@Kudi¬†¬†That is true, but CO2 is still the biggest threat for long term climate change.
author: Trey K

text:
¬†@Trey K¬†¬†It is true that CO2 is mainly produced by fossil fuel burning, and yes, CO2 lasts way longer in the atmosphere than most other greenhouse gases, however its effect is much weaker in terms of affecting things like climate change in comparison to other greenhouse gases. I mean not to say that CO2 emissions are not harmful, I would be one of the last to say that. However the greenhouses gases produced by the animal agriculture industries such as methane and nitrous oxide, especially by factory farming, as well as the negative impact of clearing the rainforest for soy farms used and exported as animal feed as well as cattle ranching land, are often purposely overlooked.
Even the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)states that "Although it accounts for only nine percent of global CO2, it generates 65 percent of human-related nitrous oxide (N2O) and 35 percent of methane (CH4), which have 296 times and 23 times the Global Warming Potential (GWP) of CO2 respectively." Also, when we are talking about saving water, resources, energy and reducing greenhouse gas emissions it is much more realistic for the average Joe to cut a bit on animal products than to expect him to stop using his car, reduce showers to a minimum and to light his house with candles. I think it is pretty clear, what strategy is more effective in terms of ecology. Not that we could not additionally be more sustainable.
author: Kudi

text:
¬†@Kudi¬†¬†CO2 does pose a bigger threat in climate change... If we stopped producing methane, it would all be gone in like 20 years. CO2 would take hundreds of years. All the methane in the atmosphere today has been produced in the last 20, the carbon, however, has been in the atmosphere since the 1800s.

There's a reason that scientists focus almost unanimously on CO2.

deforestation is a big problem because we no longer have plant life to convert CO2 to oxygen. It accelerates the power of CO2.
author: Trey K

text:
+Trey K  IF we are looking for solutions that could relatively quickly easen climate change and maybe even preven run-away climate change, we could massively decrease the amounts of greenhouse gases such asmethane and nitrous oxide within a few decades with changing our way of eating, as opposed to CO2 within centuries. And I think it IS easier for themajority of the world population, especially in Western Nations to change theirdiets instead of their mode of creating energy. At least within the current frame of corporate plutocratic democracy that is prevalent in the majority of countries of the western hemisphere. And the reason why no one wants to talk in terms of ecology about animal agriculture, meat, dairy and egg consumption is not because there is a scientific consensus on which greenhouse gas we should focus the most, but because politicians and also environmentalists are afraid to touch upon the peoples¬¥ oh so touchy and sacred hamburger patty and steak and instead talk about sorting the trash, recycling more and taking shorter showers.
I am sorry, but this is laughable.


If we are to tackle the impeding devastating effects of climate change in this century, we need to start to talk about all aspects of it, not just CO2 and fossil fuels. The data is available, but even most environmentalist ignore it in order not to upset anyone. We need to radically change our perception on other ecological aspects that impact our environment in order to be effective.
author: Kudi

text: +Kudi This is true, however introducing such a large change doesn't sound very feasible. A lot of meat industries are thriving and such radical lifestyle change can be very difficult for the average person, so instead of encouraging people towards an environmentalist viewpoint it'd just drive them away because people are scared of radical change especially so for major animal product corporations and the many people who work in it, eh just my two cents.
author: Brian Lim

text: ¬†@Brian Lim¬†¬†Such changes may be challenging for people, but that should not mean that they are not addressed at all. People might have a hard time eating less fast food, but does not mean that healthy eating is not being encouraged and promoted. And yes many people are employed in the meat industries, however a great number of people are also working in the fossil fuel sector, but most people don¬¥t have problem condemning them. And people who challenged, criticized and wanted to do something about the status quo have often throughout history being called radical, irrational, sentimental or extreme, regardless if it was about the abolition of slavery, opposition of anti-semitism, the rights of women & homosexuals or the protection of the environment.
author: Kudi

text: ¬†@Kudi¬†¬†That is very true, i agree with that. Though i have quite a lot of friends who know the consequences of meat and has been discussed a lot however many refuse to budge including myself. Such issues can't just be solved just because the people know it even more so since meat in my country is actually more readily available than vegetables, how can one possibly boycott meat or oil, unless through the government's help like how they tax carbon emissions probably they could do so with meat. Some issues just can't be placed in the hands of the public imo.
author: Brian Lim

text: ¬†@Brian Lim¬†¬†I don¬¥t think any democratic government is going to change something widespread as the consumption of meat as long their is no public majority in favor of changing the status quo or need reforms & changes. Placing one¬¥s sole hopes for change on the government and the people in power is like hoping for a drug addict to stop using drugs without any outside force motivating or forcing him to change. We people need to be the avant garde of progress and change, not the state apparatus and the 1%
author: Kudi

text:
+Kudi We do not need to stop eating animal foods as they are extremely valuable and nutritious. I think all this vegan hype is dangerous and complete nonsense. Humans have been consuming animal products for millenia.


However what needs to happen is we need to RADICALLY change the way we are farming and producing foods. Factory farming is disastrous for the environment. Humanity needs to go back to small local farms that provide food for people in the area where healthy animals feed on their natural diets and re fertilize the land without the need for importing massive amounts of grains and soy.¬†


Also I do agree with what you say about people generally eating way too many animal foods. There is no need to eat meat 3x a day or drink 3 quarts of milk a day as seems to be the norm for many in this insane society.¬†


In my opinion we are just too many on this earth which means there are also many more twisted ,selfish,lazy,useless and self destructive individuals who do not care for what happens to this world or future generations as can clearly be seen by reading some of these comments. Which means large destructive industries and their corporate greed are allowed to thrive. I honestly think mankind will have to learn the hard way and there will be a huge extinction wave at some point caused by our unsustainable manner of living on this planet.
author: Shiro Kotomine

text: ¬†@Anthony Ocran¬†¬†If we are able to stop destroying life diversity and ecosystems through our way of living, our economic activities and food production one could say that we don¬¥t need to eat animals. However, just because something has been done for a long time, it does not mean that it is morally acceptable, rational or just. I like a quote from the now deceased jewish writer Isaac Bashevis Singer on this topic:¬†‚ÄúPeople often say that humans have always eaten animals, as if this is a justification for continuing the practice. According to this logic, we should not try to prevent people from murdering other people, since this has also been done since the earliest of times.‚Äù Same would go for slavery, discrimination of women & other ethnicities, rape, etc. It is not a good argument for justifying a questionable act.
author: Kudi

text: ¬†@Kudi¬† I'm sorry but that makes no sense. We do not eat animal foods because killing and eating them has anything to do with justice. We eat them because our fysiology has evolved over millions of years in such a manner that the human body requires some essential nutrients that can only be found in their most bio-available form in animal products. Many people will become very sick when they abstain from animal foods completely. Because their nutritional types require these foods. This is a rational and logical reason. Why would it not be considered acceptable under human morales when we only take what we need to stay healthy as all sorts of organisms around the globe do in their natural habitats. I am not for mass factory farming of animals. This practice is what's truly disgusting. Animals should be allowed to live in healthy clean environments while consuming their natural foods and be put down in the most humane manner possible. Murdering people in hatred and destroying entire ecosystems to sathe ones excessive greed and hunger for power is another thing entirely. Besides Justice is ultimately just an abstract concept created by mankind so we can live in harmony with eachother and our planet's inhabitants. While I think it's important.It really shouldn't have any further meaning to it.
author: Shiro Kotomine

text: ¬†@Anthony Ocran¬†¬†And if you were wrong about your hypothesis that animal products are necessary for us? Wouldn¬¥t your argument for killing (even if it was in a "humane" way) and eating animals fall apart? Because if it is not necessity, but convenience & enjoyment driving our actions, the question of justice should justifiably be brought back to the discussion
author: Kudi

text: ¬†@Kudi¬†¬†For me personally it's definitly become purely a necessity. I have been on any vegan diet you can imagine for years believing I didn't need to eat animal foods until I almost died of malnourishment. I eat animals only to remain healthy and for me that's worth killing them for. Just as any other creature in nature will kill in order to remain healthy and survive. I don't care much for sacrificing this or that food because I enjoy it or it's convenient unlike 85% of americans who overconsume certain foods just because they are addicts without considering the ramifications for their health or for the world we live in. You can make delicious recipes out of any diet. It's just a matter of adjusting. So yes I agree with you when we talk about the majority of the populace. In any case from a purely nutritional perspective I do not agree with or think it is necessary nor a good idea to force people to go vegan in order to drastically reduce greenhouse gasses. I think it's more important to focus on radically changing the unsustainable manner of producing food that now revolves largely around a system that seeks to generate the most profit and not what's best for our planet. In other words corporate greed is a big problem like Mister Leonardo says. We as people have the power to invoke change to a certain extend though if only enough people are willing to take action and change their lifestyles.
author: Shiro Kotomine

text: ¬†@Anthony Ocran¬†¬†But if one is in favor of rather drastic change, should not oneself at least to a certain degree him/herself take some form of decisive action? I think to stop eating meat is a relatively realistic prospect for almost all people living in "first" and "second" world countries, at least in urban areas. I don¬¥t think radical change in this sector is going to come from the meatless monday or grassfed meat "movement", if we truly want to change things ecologically for the better.
author: Kudi

text:
¬†@Kudi¬†¬†Well. Sacrificing my health and falling back into sickness is not an option for me personally. I've come a long way in this area. I absolutely need my animal foods though I eat very little meat.

I believe we can shut down these mass producing meat industries by simply refusing to eat any sort of animal product that doesn't come from local small farms and I think that will automatically lead people to consume less meat.
If people would do that on a massive scale that would certainly help the environment a lot on the area of animal agriculture without having to deny people their nutrition. Have you seen the kind of wastes concentrated animal feeding operations generate? And it's not just massive and concentrated quantities of greenhouse gasses.

These large factories are polluting the air,food and water supply with millions of sickened and dead animals and their toxic waste products that are not fit to serve as fertilizer. Not to mention the horrible circumstances these animals need to live in.

These practices need to be banned asap but people don't care unfortunately and don't want to change their lifestyles not even one bit ...as I'm sure you have noticed. It's not just on the people though these large industries have too much power and they are clever as to make sure their products are the cheapest and most convenient to buy and utilize.
author: Shiro Kotomine

text: ¬†@Anthony Ocran¬†¬†Personally I think our biggest problem as a species concerning our ecological destruction of the environment is our view of ourselves of being apart from our environment rather than being a part of it. And if we do not change our ways of thinking about the relationship that we have with our habitat as well as the rest of the species we share this planet with, we are going to pay a very dire price for our artificial sense superiority in addition for our ignorance concerning these serious issues.
author: Kudi

text: ¬†@Kudi¬†¬†Very true words and I fear this is what will have to happen before anything changes.¬†
author: Shiro Kotomine

text: ¬†@Anthony Ocran¬†¬†Let¬¥s hope it does not have to come to that.
author: Kudi

text:
Bief is the most "expensive" meat to produce, they need more grain per kilogram of meat, I eat it 5 times a year roughly. Same goes for most people in my country (Portugal), my family, as well as almost all others, have only used motorized vehicles in large numbers for 15-20 years, our sewer line got to my street.. last year, electricity just got to my grandma¬¥s house 2 years ago.
You guys leave these concise comments on how to help, how to stop climate change, well, who are you talking to? People with access to the internet have the biggest carbon footprints by far (I mean in general).

 Seems like all you are doing is trying to convince someone else to do the sacrifices for you, to solve the problem you created, the rest of the world has just recently joined in the suicide train.

Stop throwing "the hot potato" at each other, you're the ones who don't know any other life but concrete jungles and all the essentials at a steps reach (again I am generalizing, but most who read this fit the description), grow up, we know who to blame, we know very well who did this, your gifts such as the PC I am using may be forgotten when we stop thinking straight.

text:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Vostok_Petit_data.svg

Take a good hard look at the graphs.¬† The Earth has been going through climate cycles which include multiple ice ages.¬† The graph line tends to get "thicker" as we approach modern time.¬† This is simply because more evidence is available.¬† The farther back you want to study, the less evidence you have to work with.

The evidence is collected from ice core samples.¬† It is possible to determine the three things listed (average temperature, co2, and "dust") from the samples.

The graphs coincide with the Earth's movements.¬† It is the Earth's various movements that result in this cycle in average temperature.¬† The evidence also shows that the changes in co2 not only display the same pattern but there is a delay.¬† The change in co2 is a result in the change in temperature and not the other way around.

Considering the mass of the Earth's oceans are about 1.4¬†√ó¬†10^21¬†kg.¬† The mass of the Earth's atmosphere is about 5.2 x 10^18 kg.¬† CO2 levels currently sit at about .04% of our atmosphere.¬† Now I know the following math isn't perfect since different gasses have different masses but this is just an estimate.¬† .04% of 5.2 x 10^18 kg is 2.08 √ó 10^15 kg.¬† With the mass of the ocean being 6 orders of magnitude greater than that of co2 and with the average temperature being 17 dec C, the ocean could dissolve all of the co2.

So why doesn't it?¬† Simple.¬† There are already gasses, including co2, dissolved in the Earth's bodies of water.¬† There exists an equilibrium.¬† Temperature plays a huge factor in this equilibrium.¬† As temperatures decrease, solubility increases and we get less co2 in the atmosphere.¬† As temperatures increase, solubility decreases and we get more co2 in the atmosphere.

Then there is the carbon cycle.¬† Not only is human credited co2 sources a small % of the over all amount of co2 released into the atmosphere.¬† The co2 doesn't stay in the atmosphere.¬† It enters the co2 cycle where only a % of the co2 actually exists as a gas in the atmosphere.

We as humans like to think that we have such a significant impact on the planet.¬† The truth is, despite there being 7 billion of us, we simply do not make much of an impact.¬† Take nuclear weapons where people believe that we have enough to wipe out the Earth.¬† Sorry but no.¬† We may have enough to wipe out us (I highly doubt it though) but we certainly can't turn Earth into a lifeless planet.¬† Just look at Chernobyl.¬† It's far from being a barren wasteland, nature is actually thriving there.

Take a look at the graph and look at between 400 thousand years ago and 350 thousand years ago.¬† How many times did the temperature 'trend upward' and for how long?¬† So we say that the average temperature has been climbing for the past 15, 20, 30 years and we think that we are causing global warming?¬† Are you kidding me.¬† It takes about a 20 thousand year span to definitely tell one way or the other if the temperature is going up, down, or holding steady.¬† Considering a 100 thousand year cycle, 30 years is what?¬† It's .03 % of the duration.¬† I'll start believing in a climate crises when we have actually been actively monitoring and studying it for about 10 thousand years minimum.¬† Until then, there is no reason to believe that the Earth won't just continue along its regular cycle.¬† Which also means that the long term trend is one of cooling down and not warming up which is only a short term trend.

Emma, no. Just no. 
It is the fourth highest cause of greenhouse gases. Behind energy production ie. burning coal, industry (burning fossil fuels & releasing gases from chemical/mineral transformation processes) and transport which solely operates on burning fossil fuels. 
Agricultural/forestry activities accounted for a combined 21%. However, in the US for example, the amount of carbon emissions sequestered (removed) from the atmosphere from these industries through biomass, dead organic matter and soils , offset those emissions by 20%. This means that most years they are in negative numbers of greenhouse gas production. So yeah, just no.

text:
I was on a week long tour to various fascinating places in the northwestern part of the country. On my way back home I had the opportunity to visit a remote village of a farming community. I was¬†
at a farmers house and he produced enough crop to feed his family for the entire year. We had a casual ¬†conversation back then and I found out the inspite of being illiterate he knew about all farming. I realized how dedicated he was in his business, I must say a master in farming methods and practices. But surprisingly he did not know who the president of India is. At that time I realized that though this man is illiterate he is able to sustain his family and that is what is needed. But when I switch on the Television I see disturbing images. Every country in the world is trying to secure its future nothing else and all this is creating an arms race. Fortunately with gods grace all our world leaders are highly stable (Mentally). A leader according to me should be like a fatherly figure. One who treats every citizen of his country as if they are his own children. People experience calm, happiness and peaceful atmosphere in his presence. That according to me are the characteristics of a great leader. But what if one fine day ¬†someone who is not that stable mentally becomes a leader.Because day by day the comfort level of individuals is increasing. Why was the united nations created ? We youngsters expect our leaders to sit together and talk and understand the strengths and weaknesses of every nation and provided them with a fitting opportunity.If ¬†people are truthful to themselves and others they need not fear anyone. That's what I have learned from the words etched at bottom of Asoka symbol in every Indian coin. We all have only one life span and we must make every possible use of it so that we are remembered for good deeds,Contributing something to the society. Deeds that make us and everyone around us happy, but not the cost of other peoples happiness.¬†

text:
What can Americans do? ¬†Senator Whitehouse proposes an American Fund Carbon Fee and Dividend Act. ¬†If we pass an annually increasing carbon fee, and give all of that fee back to citizens, energy from coal will get more expensive than energy from wind and solar, and our carbon emissions will slow. ¬†This will slow the rise of the oceans. ¬†

Consider joining your local Citizens‚Äô Climate Lobby group and join in writing letters to your representatives, and convincing others we need a Carbon Fee with 100% Dividend. ¬†(This is the way the Citizens‚Äô Climate Lobby phrases an annually increasing carbon fee, where 100% of that fee is returned to you and every U.S. citizen.) ¬†The carbon fee will cause energy and gasoline prices to rise, and you will get that fee back so you can afford those rising ¬†prices. ¬†Eventually energy from coal will cost more than energy from wind and solar, and US carbon emissions will slow. ¬†The border adjustment on imports will raise the price of foreign goods so US goods can compete. ¬†The border adjustment on exports will lower the price of goods made in the US, so they can compete with foreign goods. ¬†Former Secretary of State George Schultz calls this a Revenue Neutral Carbon Tax. ¬†It is not a tax, because 100% of the ‚Äútax‚Äù is returned to you and all U.S. citizens. ¬†This ‚Äútax‚Äù does not go to the government.

An economic study by REMI says that after 20 years this carbon fee and dividend would provide 2.8 million jobs, save 228,000 lives and decrease carbon dioxide emissions 52% in the United States.¬†

If friends doubt global warming, say ‚ÄúOK forget global warming. ¬†Let‚Äôs pass this carbon fee and dividend because it will create 2.8 million more jobs, raise the GDP and save 228,000 lives after 20 years. ¬†(And ‚Äúincidentally‚Äù, we‚Äôll decrease carbon dioxide emissions 52%.) ¬† ¬†¬†

http://citizensclimatelobby.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/The-Economic-Climate-Fiscal-Power-and-Demographic-Impact-of-a-National-Fee-and-Dividend-Carbon-Tax-6.9.14.pdf

Oil¬†company CEO's must be close to dying¬†from laughter.¬†Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas, it's not up for some kind of debate, it's not an opinion is it?¬†We are¬†UNNECESSARILY emitting millions of tonnes of it, gambling on what the effect might be. Presumably people think life on earth is worth a gamble? What do you even get¬†if this gamble "pays off"? It's hard not to roll around laughing yourself. Well if the gamble "pays off" we get increasingly expensive,¬†dirty,¬†shrinking energy reserves?¬†Sounds great. Plus ever¬†increasing amounts of¬†air pollution from cars and factories, pollution¬†that is probably slowly giving us all cancer.¬†This CO2¬†is also being absorbed in large quantities by¬†our oceans, converting it to¬†carbonic acid, causing acidification. This threatens any life that lives in, or depends on the ocean, including us.¬†Truly¬†apocalyptic¬†quantities of Methane (many times worse than CO2)¬†could be released from the deep ocean if it's temperature rises by just a couple of degrees. text: So, Consider a man who drives a 1972 Ford LTD with a 400 big block that gets 7 miles per gallon on a good day.¬† But it hasn't seen a good day in a while.¬† He has 2 cylinders not firing so there is raw, unburned gasoline spewing out the exhaust.¬† The heater fan is out, but if he lets it warm up for an hour each morning, it gets pretty warm inside.¬† He gets home after sunset so when the timer for his outside lights went out, he just started leaving them on all day so his yard is not dark.¬† He has three televisions which he leaves on 24/7 to give the appearance that someone is home.¬† He has no attic insulation, so his heater runs almost constantly, just like his water heater since it started to leak a little.¬† Recycle?¬† What's that?¬† He burns his trash out back-all of it.¬† What doesn't burn gets pushed into the garbage pit and buried.¬† He earns a little extra money on the weekends painting cars in his driveway.¬† He doesn't need a ventilation system; The overspray blows away with the wind.¬† But he really is a good guy, so when he hears about global warming, he is legitimately concerned.¬† He wants to do his part to help preserve the planet.¬† So he goes to his computer (already on, so there's no waiting).¬† He reads up on itand as far as he can tell, he IS a Big Part of the Problem.¬† He thinks of all those years that, if he had only known...But, now he knows and he's determined to make a change starting now.¬† He goes right down to the grocery store, and when he gets home, he clears out the entire freezer and most of the refrigerator and re-stocks it with his new, earth friendly food.¬† EGGPLANT!¬† That will be his main course at every meal.¬† He is sad that he didn't know sooner, but he's willing to make up for it.¬† He is grateful beyond explanation that he found that VEGAN website.¬† No longer will he be a carnivore, not since he learned that people who eat meat are solely responsible for killing the planet.¬† He never really ate all that much meat anyway, but now he is meat free and he feels good about knowing how much he is helping to save the planet-just by cutting meat out of his diet.¬† And oh Yeah, he will start wearing cotton gloves at work too.¬† It's straight to the burn pit for the leather ones...¬† So, Tell me VEGANS...What have your lies accomplished?¬† Everyone should look at his/her personal activities and determine where the best, most productive conservation efforts can be made.¬† For one to think he/she is doing his/her part by simply becoming a vegan is foolish.¬† For vegans to spread their outright lies about carnivores destroying the planet is counter-productive.¬† What's worse is to think that some of them are so fkn stupid, they believe it.

text: For all those climate change deniers out there, let's look at this another way. The extraction process of oil, coal, and natural gas is very destructive. Hundreds of mountains of the Appalachians don't exist because of mountain top removal for coal. Many hundreds of oil spills and disasters, one of the most recent being the Deep Water Horizon disaster.¬† What about those giant lakes of coal ash left over from coal burning power plants? Yea that runoff, which is full of heavy metals including mercury, finds its way into our water table.¬† Now there's the great controversy of the many chemicals companies use to frack natural gas that seep into the water table. It doesn't make common sense to continue endangering ourselves with resources that are irrefutably obsolete. We have the technology RIGHT NOW to replace all of that.¬† The carbon tax isn't just about global warming, whether you want to believe in that or not. It's also about protecting ourselves, our local economies, our health, and our wildlife. You want common sense? Go renewable.

text:
Saying leaders of the world don't pretend for a living is a bit laughable. ¬†World leaders pretend to care about the lower and middle class, they could care less. ¬†They are just acting themselves, putting on a face to deceive people into thinking they care. ¬†

While I think global warming or whatever you call it is propaganda, I do believe it's irresponsible to damage our environment, and it leaves scars on our souls. ¬†Unfortunately the biggest culprits are big industry who spill toxic waste into rivers, oil spills, nuclear power that can cause catastrophic damage when compromised a la Fukushima, spraying chemicals in the air which are supposedly helping with cooling (yeah right). ¬†The problem is the powers that be, who have the potential to make an actual impact, don't give a shit and will never change anything, no matter how many emphatic speeches are given, because they are the ones orchestrating it. ¬†They applaud the emphatic speeches, and are the ones who put people like Leo up here to tug at everyone's heart-strings. ¬†

But it's just like how the NBA "cares" about kids, throw a commercial on with Lebron James helping children out at a local school, but then go on to be a "role model" that tells kids fame, money and power are the most important things because the whole lifestyle revolves around that. ¬†Watching a bunch of spoiled millionaire's who are worshiped like gods for putting a ball in a hoop, have carte blanche to get away with any legal trouble, who engage in a bunch of petty gossip on twitter and play the entertainment game is one of the worst things you can put in children's minds. ¬†It's a complete contraction of itself by telling them these are "great" people and enough of them buy it, including myself growing up.

To really change, it needs to start on a personal level, not buy so much crap we don't need, stop supporting big industry the best we can, and write to them to tell them why, turn off the television, pay no attention to politicians, boycott sports and all the other poison for our minds and work on making our family's stronger, not upgrading everytime a new f'n iPhone comes out, or giving your 12 year old one so he can show off to his friends and enslave his own mind because he's not mature enough to handle it. ¬†We need to start producing things like food for ourselves if possible, or having some tangible skill, being pro-active in our own education and health, learn how to cope with life without pills and pharmaceutical drugs, and investing in the future by exposing all the BS in the world to our children so they don't fall for fancy speech's by millonaire's and billionaire's on how to save the world, instead of raising them in a world of fantasy where it's only cute things and puppy dogs. ¬†We need to teach kids to value integrity and not going for the quick buck, or the easy solution. ¬†Teach them critical thinking and stop promoting that going to college is what education is all about. ¬†What it's all about is enslaving them to the debt system, most kids aren't mature enough to know why they are in college in the first place. ¬†

I don't care how "educated" you are, whether it's Princeton, Yale or you're an astrophysicist, if you can't see that people like Obama or any other politician is just a paid actor, you're ignorant. ¬†I'm not saying anyone who goes to college is an idiot, not at all, it's more important to understand WHY you are really there in the first place, and I think that most people who are there who can't see through the most basic logic of someone says something, and does the complete opposite, that means they are a liar and you shouldn't rely on them. ¬†The problem we keep looking to leaders who have never historically done anything but work for the elite, while knowing all the clever tricks to make most people buy into their bullshit and make the masses victims of the Stockholm Syndrome.

I'm not making a judgement on Mr. DiCaprio. ¬†I just think he's being used as a pawn. ¬†I'm not one to say he should put his money where his mouth is and sell off his fortune to help the world, he's probably doing a lot more than many people do, and is doing what he feels is right and is in a position to spread a message he believes in, or maybe he's fully aware that what he is doing is full of lies and is a conniving bastard. ¬†I don't know him personally nor his intentions, and I've never seen him say anything to make me think less of him from the little I've seen in his public life, though I'm not one to follow celebrity's lives. ¬†The point is, no matter how inspiring the speech may be, or what his true intentions are behind it, he's allowed to that podium for a reason: Because he's a useful idiot. ¬†I don't mean than in a vulgar manner but more a sad manner, because when things that are positive and inspirational are just being used by a deceptive and sinister agenda engineered by puppet masters who truly don't give a shit about anyone but themselves and preservation of their wealth and power at the expense of the people, it's one of the worst forms of deception out there because so many will fall for it.

I think that the source of misinformation, as in many other topics, is "small thinking".
The climate has been changing since the Earth 1st had a climate. We had temperatures much lower than the currents ones, as well as much higher ones. At one point, in the Jurassic era, CO2 levels were 5 to 10 times the ones of today, and yet, lower temperatures.
The big and the little ice age. Were they because there weren't enough green house gases? What has been changing temperatures since the beginning of what we know as climate? Certainly not green house gases, let alone man-made ones.

We do need, however, to reduce or eliminate entirely our CO2 emissions. Not for climate sake. but for our own direct one.

I encourage people to research the impact that cosmic rays have on our climate. When one does, one finds a direct and clear correlation between the amount of cosmic rays absorbed by Earth and its climate.

Please, take a look at this graph and, in the interests of fair information, test its veracity with information from other sources.
http://jonova.s3.amazonaws.com/graphs/cosmic-ray/svensen-cosmic-rays-tropospheric-temperature-crop.gif

http://joannenova.com.au/2010/02/if-carbon-didnt-warm-us-what-did/

If¬†you look at the¬† study which came up with the 97% number [The¬† Pew Centre, I think]¬†, you will see that¬†it comes from¬†just 77 of¬†79 climatologists, and¬†not¬†ALL the climatologists on Earth as you claim. Also the question that these climatologists responded to was¬†something like this, "Do you believe that human activities could have contributed to climate change..."? Now that¬†is the kind of question that everyone can¬†answer yes to, even the most hardened sceptics would probably agree with that. The problem is with the language used when the results of such surveys are released to the media. That is when the subtle, but dangerous alterations are made in the narrative which distort the true findings.
As far as the old smoking chestnut goes, this really is just an attempt to dismiss sceptic arguments without addressing the issue. The simple reality is that there are thousands of scientists worldwide who don't agree with the catastrophic scenario¬†ideas being actively hyped by some.¬†Richard Lindzen [MIT], John¬†Christy[U of Col], Patrick Michaels, are just a few and there are many more.
In regards to the laws of physics, the Earth is not exempt from them, that is not¬†the argument. The question is HOW MUCH of the warming that we have observed is due to CO2, and how much is natural. The IPCC modellers¬†have assumed that ALL of the warming of the last 50 years is from CO2. There is no scientific basis for making¬†that assumption and¬†the evidence in fact suggests that CO2 has much less of an effect than we previously thought. The¬†IPCC reports have started to reflect this evidence, in the down wards revision of the climate sensitivity number.

text:
I agree with the message but I think we are all clearly underestimating the true scale of this problem. Make no mistake, petroleum runs the world. Everything we rely on gets shipped by land, sea and air and almost all of it uses petroleum in some fashion. Whether it's a ship carrying cargo half way around the world, a plane carrying people and goods the same, or trains (often using diesel) to carry them inland and trucks (again powered by diesel) to get them to stores and finally you who visit the store using gasoline in your car.

This entire mechanism cannot be changed quickly. But certainly I am in agreement that it must change. Make no mistake, however, this will not be easy nor cheap. As finding ways to make alternatives work will take decades to transition to. As even what we have today, it's still out of reach for many people.

I myself would love to put solar panels on my roof, but that's 30 grand. I would love to have an electric car (say a Tesla) but that's 100 grand. I'm not rich. I can only do so much. Beyond that, we need solutions to tackle beyond the consumers share. Industry has to start chiming in on this. And sadly, I don't think we'll be powering ships with electricity any time soon (unless they start running on nuclear fuel). Same goes for jets or trucks. Those are the big problems that will make the greatest impact.

author: Jesse Saretzky

text:
¬†In the early 1800's: for the first time in human history, there were a billion people on earth. Then we discovered the value of coal, oil and gas. Human population expands thanks to the incredible energy we can harvest from these three materials, and they fuel industrialization and growth. 100 years later, 1910's: 2 billion. 40 years later, 1950's: 3 billion. 20 years later, 1970's: 4 billion. 15 years on, 1990's: 6 billion. And 2011: 7 billion humans on earth.
¬†In 200 years, the global population has multiplied by 7 thanks to fossil fuels. But now the question is: What happens when we run out? What happens when in 30, 50, 150 years time, there will be nothing more to extract from the acid ground?
¬†What happens when we are up to 10 billion humans on a planet that can hold only 1 billion?

text:
It's a telling sign of anthropogenic climate change deniers' ignorance when they use arguments such as "the climate is constantly changing with or without us" or even worse "warming where? this was the coldest summer in ages in my town, must be a lie!". Point 1 is well known, and completely irrelevant and point 2 is the definition of self centered idiocy. They are also the first to point out that it's probably just government/industry attempting to push agenda, but fail to recognize that the oil/power industry is completely responsible for seeding the denial of human impact on climate, and continue to right this moment. Take a trip to Beijing and walk the streets at midday, then come back and tell me we are incapable of effecting anything by pumping out pollutants and carbons.

Source: I'm an Environmental Science/Economics grad. I could make more money by selling out and supporting the power industry's agenda, but I would prefer to look out for our species instead of fucking up my descendants' future.

text: I hope Climate Change activists will focus more strongly on the fact that a lot of climate threatening behaviour is not only the result of malevolence or ignorance, but of dilemma situations. For instance, even an understanding, pro-activist industrialist will be unable to take environmentally responsible measures, if such actions raise his company's costs so much that he loses out to irresponsible competitors and thus goes out of business. Hence, we have to design economic policies in a way so that doing the right thing ALSO becomes the economically feasible or even profitable thing, which is only possible if all relevant institutions and companies are equally compelled, by law, to meet certain standards. We must not continue to frame the climate change issue as a fight or a blame game between the smart vs. the ignorant, or the responsible vs. the greedy. These sides may exists, but they are not the most relevant aspect. We have to come together and view environmentally responsible behaviour as a current dilemma of rational choice and then create an institutional environment which actually incentivises responsible action.

text: ¬†@SHUTTERSHOT45¬†¬†Look at ice core data. You can see the history of CO2 levels. There is a naturally induced rise and fall of CO2, but after the industrial revolution until the present, CO2 levels shoot straight up. There are videos of how these ice cores were obtained and how it works. Also global warming is not an accurate term to use because there are a variety of climatic effects. Some regions may experience more droughts, others increased rainfall or floods, or we see the collapse of circulating currents that regulate warm and moist conditions which can cool certain regions. My point is, everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but at least do some credible research before you jump on a bandwagon.

Not everything you read on the internet is true, but likewise, not everything you read on the internet is false. You need to take into account the credibility of the source and the evidence they have.

text: Leonardo proves the undeniable point that it has been the ways of thinking hammered out by institutions over hundreds of years that have ravaged this planet, and it is up to the human enterprise to manage these nit-wit, ill-gotten institutions so that our children might have a place to put their feet and a sky to walk under. Taking the abundance of the world and turning it into a finite resource for companies and lobbyists to be peddled for money on a competition based market is shit-brained. These kinds of ideals turn people into shoddy products and shoddy'er consumers, while the brutal and ruthless rise to the top standing with their foot on your shoulder. Soon there are no fish left in the oceans, no trees left on the planet, the sudden toxification of the air we breathe by turning a blind aye to the effects of burning coal and oil for hundreds of years, then what will we eat or breath? Money? The way to get away from that is to turn your back on the modes of thinking that have been pushed through by the capitalistic institutions and start to form models of society where Competition is replaced with cooperation, and co-creation. This one small change in the way markets operate in today's monetary system could alter an un-forseen, sudden, and drastic shift in the worlds current paradigm, possibly a shift to a resourced based economy where the goods and services that are turned out aren't for how much money they can get but the good of the people. Eventually leading to even more baroque and empowering vistas of brotherhood.

text:
That post started out really well until you got to the part where you think capitalism is the problem. Capitalism is the only solution. Capitalism incentivizes cooperation and co-creation. The markets in all first world nations are actually either fascist or socialistic. They incentivize greed and corruption. And government is the cause of it all.

Government is the problem. Without government force, all businesses and corporations abide by the free market. And in a true free market, the consumer is the king. What we have now is corporations teaming up with government to steal and make money off of the consumers. This isn't capitalism. It's not even close.

Capitalism means nothing more than voluntary exchange between two or more parties. It is the purest of markets. How the government has brainwashed people into thinking capitalism is evil is just one more thing I'll never understand.

The absolute best part about capitalism is that the greediest of companies have to serve their consumers as best as they can if they want the most amount of money possible. So you can be greedy and selfless at the exact same time in a capitalistic society. You simultaneously are helping people and maximizing your profits.

In our markets now, if companies want the most amount of money possible, one option they have is to just bribe the government to pass a law saying only they can provide that product. Or the company can push for super expensive and stiff regulations so smaller businesses can't pay for them and therefore can't compete.

But these corrupt companies are just following their best incentive for money. Without government force, their incentives entirely shift back towards pleasing their consumers to the best of their abilities. Life is all about incentives. That's how markets work.
author: travz21

text: ¬†@travz21¬† Travz, that's all nice in theory -- if consumers had all the facts. But the science is obscured by big-industry smoke-and-mirrors, as it was with the now-acknowledged scientific truth about the harmfulness of cigarette smoking. In true capitalism, prices for things would represent their true cost. Gas would be $15 per gallon because the companies that supply it would pay for the bad repercussions (externalities) of their product. Then consumers could make a fair choice about whether they want it, or whether they'd prefer the development of something cleaner and less problematic to use as fuel. Government is only the problem if it is a puppet of industry, as it is today in the US. Demand better leaders. Industry exists to make money...period. In your dreamworld industry has the consumers' best interest at heart because they have to. This is not how it is in the real world. Wake up. Oh, and if you think "the government has brainwashed people into thinking capitalism is evil," you are living in Bizarro-Land.

text:
¬†@*****¬†¬†China is still a major area of concern in dealing with atmospheric pollution. While not necessarily scapegoating, developed nations definitely shift attention to developing nations due to their lack of monetary and technological means to properly improve their pollutants. Given the vast array of technological production in China and other developing nations, it is, as it should be, a definite concern if these nations don't have proper safety regulations in place in terms of air quality.

Also, corporate greed is only a by-product of the pollution of the atmosphere. It is still present regardless of whether you want to believe that human civilization is the main propagator or not. Saying that there is no need for alternative energy just because greed is an active by-product is ridiculous. People are capitalistic in nature, as long as there is demand, there will be shifts in power accompanied by greed. The environmental demand for these changes far outweigh any detrimental economical and sociological factors.

text:
It is absolutely man made. Look at how we've treated our forests, look at how much cattle and pigs we are raising, cars we are driving, planes we are flying, carbon we are releasing. This is not some made up fantasy, this is real. The actions of men have pushed the planet into a period of warming, when ice core records show it should be cooling.¬†

What we need is to stop cutting down Earth's lungs, stop pumping out CO2 and methane into our atmosphere and START REVERSING THE PROCESS by planting more trees and building machines that can suck up carbon. It's not simple, but if we do it, then billions of lives will be saved, ecosystems will continue to thrive and our kids will have good clean air to breath. I think the risks are high enough that real action is more than necessary.

And concerning antarctica, read this carefully. Educate yourself. Like you said, the Earth is a dynamic system.

author: Nope Nopeington

text:
¬†@Nope Nopeington¬†
I'm a climate scientist in training, and the science is clear. The article you just shared is misleading at best. Climate change is an absolutely dangerous phenomenon. Whether or not every scientist is confident that something catastrophic will happen is a different story, because the Earth is an extremely complex system and there is just no way of knowing for certain what will happen.

Climate models prove 1 thing: the butterfly effect. You change one variable and the entire system starts to act differently.
Right now, the key variables are deforestation, changing albedo (from melting ice caps and changing landscapes) and greenhouse gas emissions, all of which are linked to human activity. Even if you don't think it's caused by humans, it is absolutely happening and it is absolutely dangerous. The science is clear. Rising sea levels is a danger to us all, droughts and floods will desecrate many areas, fresh water dumping into the North Atlantic may stop the Thermohaline circulation which will have dramatic effects on Europe's climate, many aspects that keep our climate stable and habitable are at risk.

Ultimately, we either need to try and reverse it for the sake of our kids, or not do anything and see what happens.
I say we try and reverse it. The risks of just waiting and seeing are much too high.

author: sharpcin

text:
¬†@sharpcin¬†
The Arctic is melting. It isn't ice-free yet, but it will reach that point sometime in the 21st century. This is a scientific, observable fact.

Greenland is also seeing a lot of melt, which is what is truly dangerous since it could disrupt the Thermohaline circulation and push Europe into a much colder climate, in addition to raising sea levels significantly, in addition to dangerous increases in algae blooms.

Now, the question in your mind is: Is it man-made? You seem convinced that it is not, or at least you have serious doubts, which is totally fine and rational. However, the evidence is there, it's clear that we are the ones raising the carbon concentration in the atmosphere. Carbon dioxide and Methane are known GHG. 1+1=2. Emissions = Warming. However, sure, maybe this would have happened regardless. Volcanoes erupt, ice melts, Earth evolves. But it's clear we are making a significant impact and that we are speeding up the process at an alarming rate.

What I'm saying is we NEED to try and reverse it, and that we have the knowledge and technology to do so. Why? Because many ecosystems will die if we don't, and we rely on many of these ecosystems to survive, from what we eat to preventing disease. In addition, most of the world's largest cities lie right on the coast. You may think we are powerless to stop it, that we should accept our fate (or rather our grandchildren's fate) but I say fuck that. Let's work together.
author: Parker DW

text:
¬†@Parks DeWi¬†¬†you know I appreciate your good intentions, and do agree that we need to reign in or even eliminate corporations that are damaging the environment absolutely.¬†

I just wholeheartedly disagree that a world governing body could or would ever accomplish that goal, centralizing political power has never in the history of mankind worked out well, in fact it almost always leads to communism or Tyranny or further war and genocide and poverty, starvation etc. etc. ¬†Nope I've been around far too long to ever believe that more government is the solution to anything. Besides there are already many hundreds or thousands or pollution regulation and laws at the local level of government, they just need to enforce the regulation and laws already on the books, why would we need to build yet another level of government bureaucracy on other levels of bureaucracy and then tax more to finance that new framework? ¬†And yes I understand climate is global and perhaps tasking that to global political body would may sound sensible but unfortunately experience tells me otherwise, building a tax base for a global government would be a grave error.

And I also have to take issue with your initial statement, the Artic isn't melting global sea ice levels are at record levels, and satellite telemetry proves that it's not only increasing in spread it's also getting much thicker, which at the very least indicates that the climate model their using is completely wrong, because the scientists don't understand why the ice mass is increasing and ithis was "completely unexpected".

You can read about it yourself and of course I'm sure there will be a convoluted explanation as to how this event still fits in with the climate model which would not surprise me in the slightest since that seems to be the norm with this whole thing... the ice is melting but it's growing, it's global warming but it's getting colder, who's held accountable?¬†

http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-25383373
author: sharpcin

text:
¬†@sharpcin¬†
We fundamentally disagree on a few points, and that cannot be helped.

However, you are wrong on some of your facts. It is not getting colder, the global temperature average is getting hotter. Local climates vary, and some areas experience colder than normal weather while others experience hotter. Climate change is also about precipitation, and that's changing noticeably. Just look at the US. It all has to do with the intricacies between ocean and air currents. Either way, it confirms global scale climate change.

And regarding your "facts" on the Arctic, I would like to quote the article you just shared:
"It's estimated that there were around 20,000 cu km of Arctic sea ice each October in the early 1980s, and so today's minimum still ranks among the lowest of the past 30 years,"
The thicker ice is melting. The cover may have bounced back slightly for a year, but the damage in the lower layors is done.
My main concern lies with Greenland, since land ice will be the main driver of rising sea levels.

http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/

Read that please

And I never said anything about governments centralizing power. Simply that governments should impose restrictions to encourage companies to find better alternatives rather than pumping out greenhouse gases like there's no tomorrow. It is not tyranny, it's practicality and a kindness to the livelihoods of future generations.
author: Parker DW

text:
¬†@Parks DeWi¬†¬†Sorry but you haven't interpreted the data correctly, the thicker ice isn't melting, take another look at the telemetry data, you see the brightly colored areas, the yellow and fusha, that represents ice thickness, and there is much more thick ice in the data from 2014 then there is in the data from 2010 it's very clear to see, also the surface area of the ice mass is much larger.¬†

It may not be as large or as thick as it was 30 years ago but who's to say that what you are cherry picking as the norm is actually the norm or even optimal? The earth is billions of years old and I'm quite sure that in a more extensive time frame your 30 year time frame data would be set in an entirely different context.

Add to this the fact taht the sea ice levels in the Antartic are at record levels since the beginning of record keeping, and the fact that the temperatures in my country which is a very large country with a northern climate are well cooler then average, and I could provide actual data for that... and you'll forgive me if I don't buy into the claim of the polar ice melting any time soon, this century or the next.... after all according to Mr. Gore those polar ice caps should have been gone by now.
author: sharpcin

text:
¬†@sharpcin¬† The ice has gotten thinner, I could name you any number of studies that I've been reading for school all confirming the measurements. But at this point in time, I think we both need to take a little internet break lol. The planet is getting hotter, winters, on average, are getting milder and milder. I repeat, on average. We have records going back thousands of years from ice cores and sediments, and the carbon concentration in the atmosphere is much higher then it should be.

Global warming could push the planet into another ice age, or bring it into any number of states. Who knows what the future holds. I just know GHG are a dangerous thing to be playing around with so carelessly. I want to live in a world where I don't have to be worried about what companies are polluting our Earth with. I'm an engineer and a climatologist in training, so I'll work myself to the bone to make sure the world is a cleaner place to live. It isn't just GHG, it's water pollution, it's deforestation, it's overfishing, it's pesticides/herbicides, it's mass consumption and reckless waste disposal.
We, as a species, have a lot of challenges ahead and habits to change. And people are arguing about Liberals being dumb and Conservatives being selfish, I think we just need to agree on the simple fact that if humanity keeps treating the planet the way it is today, then in 100 years the planet won't be such a beautiful place for our grandchildren to live in.

Anyway, keep a watchful eye on how things progress. Everyone should stay as informed as they can. Goodnight to you, stranger from the internet.
author: Parker DW

text:
¬†@*****¬†
Not quite. My mind is very open though thanks.
author: Parker DW

text: ¬†@*****¬† I appreciate that, thank you.
author: Parker DW

text:
¬†@Parks DeWi¬†¬†Hello again, I have taken further time to investigate "Climate Change" and it seems the further I dig the more contraindicating information I find. I agree we should not be destroying any old growth forests, and we should dispose or our waste carefully and recycle as oftern as possible, but I have become even more resolute in my opinion that "climate change" is not man made, and that CO2 at the current levels pose any threat to the planet what so ever. According to every stat I found the earth is in a cooling trend and has been for some time.

Today‚Äôs average global temperature is 14.5 C. This compares with a low of about 12 C during the periods of maximum glaciation in this ice age, to an average of 22 C during the greenhouse ages, one of which occurred prior to the most recent ice age. During the greenhouse ages, there was no ice on either poles and all the land was tropical and sub-tropical. As recently as three million years ago the Canadian Arctic islands were forested.
author: sharpcin

text:
¬†@sharpcin¬†
Ok well thank you for doing some research, but the Earth has been steadily warming since the Industrial Revolution. But anyway, whether or not its caused by us is irrelevant really, because I'm saying this is a serious problem that needs to be addressed by all of our governments and corporations.
Anyway I encourage you to continue reading up on the subject!

As long as we agree that deforestation and proper waste disposal needs to become a top priority, we can be friends :-). I just don't want to have to worry to death about my kids and their kids, knowing that at some point we are going to have a widespread shortage of resources if we don't start taking care of our trash, and the atmosphere will become toxic if we don't stop pumping out carbon, arsenic and other harmful chemicals, all the while cutting down all of the oxygen producing forests. Not to mention animal farms are growing larger and larger, which is a breeding ground for new diseases, while we are killing off many of the worlds ecosystems that keep harmful diseases at bay.
Humans needs to find a way to be in balance with the world around us, and the people in power should be working towards that goal... But they aren't. It's all about the bottom line.
author: Parker DW

text: ¬†@Parks DeWi¬†¬†agreed, the earth does not have unlimited resources and recycling should be one of our top priorities, just about everything can be recycled, if we want to create jobs in this economy I think recycling is going to become the new "mining" or "resource" sector as resources become increasingly scarce. My main point of disagreement are with regards to man made weather effects and CO2, so we can agree to disagree on that, I just do not agree on any kind of Cap & Trade carbon credit system, it's a tax on CO2 and a very slippery slope when you consider that pretty much all human activity generates CO2 and will need a carbon credit allowance to exist.¬†
author: sharpcin

text:
¬†@sharpcin¬†
Well, at some point someone is going to need to put some rules in place so humans don't continue on this current path. It's up to the people in power, corporations and governments, and to us as individuals, to make the necessary changes.
What those changes will be, how they work and how they will affect our individual freedoms depends on how much responsibility each person is willing to take on.
Are we willing to admit that our activities are affecting life on our planet in a very negative way? Are we willing to take responsibility for our actions and the actions of our ancestors? Are we willing to pay the price so our kids don't have to?
No one WANTS to feel guilty or blamed for everyone's actions, no one WANTS to feel cheated or treated unfairly, but we also don't want our kids to suffer because of our actions...
So I hope we as a species can get there, but until then I'll just do what I can in my little part of the world.

Anyway, sorry for the cheese fest. Having one of those days. Take care.
author: Parker DW

text:
¬†@Parks DeWi¬†¬†Well, this is exactly why I said at the very beginning that further centralizing government and giving them more power to tax and regulate every day citizens is not the solution, that only makes it easier for the big corporations to buy off the people in power and they continue to pollute, besides 95% off the pollution problem is the very big corporations, I don't think you can honestly say the real problem is the everyday Joe driving too and from work, besides like I've already said I don't believe it's CO2, which data shows that has been at many multiples the current level throughout ¬†earth's history, I believe the real problem is the lead, mercury and other heavy metals being emitted into the atmosphere, and somehow that's always ignored and CO2 gets the blame, which is as you know what plants breathe and helps plant based life flourish.

Anyhow, I think we need to use our heads this time around and come up with a different solution other then the old standard solution of more beurocrats, more bureaucracies, more taxes, etc. etc. which clearly does not work in any case, whether you believe in man made climate change or not, this is an ineffective approach. If anything the best way to tackle this problem is to decentralize.

author: SVAFnemesis

text:
Meat and dairy is addictive, and very hard to remove from your diet, which is the main reason why we can't get over our mass consumption of it. To remove all instances of meat and dairy consumption everywhere by tomorrow is unrealistic. However, getting people aware of the effects of consuming meat and dairy on the environment and on your own body may help turn people towards lower meat consumption or a vegan diet.

To create 1 kilo of beef you need 100,000 liters of water,¬†chickens takes 3,500 liters of water. In comparison, soybean production uses 2,000 liters for kilogram of food produced; rice, 1,912; wheat, 900; and potatoes, 500 liters.¬†More than half the U.S. grain and nearly 40 percent of world grain is being fed to livestock rather than being consumed directly by humans.¬†If all the grain currently fed to livestock in the United States were consumed directly by people, the number of people who could be fed would be nearly 800 million. These are all statistics from 1997, you would think that 17 years later more people would be aware of this problem.¬†

Watch 'cowspiracy' for meat and dairy's effect on global warming or 'forks over knives' on why to go vegan. Go educate yourselves! : )
