author: speedsociety

text: ¬†@speedsociety¬†¬†Which become null if you adjust production standards and practices. Demand does not necessarily drive production means entirely. There is both overproduction and poor production of meat, but that doesn't equate to ceasing all consumption of meat.
author: longliverocknroll5

text: ¬†@longliverocknroll5¬†¬†Like i said, i do not understand where this assumption comes from that we all need to stop eating meat entirely. That is not the point, i eat meat as well but i make sure it is organic beef. Thats costs a bit more which is what drives most people to buy lower standard meat that comes from mass production. If people would appreciate meat more and be willing to pay more for good production standards, consumption would decrease and so would mass production. But with the current standards of cheap meat that everyone is accustomed to, that's not going to change anytime soon. In the end all that interests people is their wallet.
author: speedsociety

text:
¬†@speedsociety¬†¬†I have a problem with the way our markets, and people in general use the term "organic". Organic is often a misused term and is not always the most practical, economical, or safe way of acquiring quality meat.

If you want truly quality meat, your best option, at least if you live in a rural setting and from my experience, is to buy from local farmers.
author: longliverocknroll5

text: ¬†@longliverocknroll5¬†¬†Then you should read up on organic beef, because that means that production needs to adhere to strict production standards that are clearly regulated. The US Department of Agriculture has clear guidelines on what certified organic beef means. Buying from local farmers if of course also a very sustainable alternative, but not all farmers care about adhering to those guidelines and it's also only suitable for people in rural areas like you pointed out already.
author: speedsociety

text: ¬†@speedsociety¬†¬†Not all products labelled as "organic" are truly organic. Mostly because truly organic is next to impossible. Not to mention the fact that companies can easily step around the guidelines with simple marketing tricks.
author: longliverocknroll5

text:
¬†@longliverocknroll5¬†¬†Certified organic means that production needs to adhere to guidelines, facilities get checked etc. Of course, there are black sheep trying to exploit this by breaking the law or using tricks but that does not invalidate the value of guidelines like these. I don't know much about the US market as i am german, but here we have multiple certification labels with varying strictness of standards and by the label one can pretty much see if the producer is taking organic seriously or just wants to use it as a marketing vehicle. The latter is a problem of course, but in general buying whatever certified organic food is still better than buying mass produced food.
In the case of meat, "certified organic" at least means that animals have not been stuffed with growth hormones and antibiotics which is also something highly problematic on a whole different level, because it leads to antibiotic resistance which could cause our lives to change in the next decade.¬†
author: speedsociety

text:
¬†@speedsociety¬†¬†Yes, U.S. markets, and more importantly the general populus, don't really check on the validity of the products they purchase. Many companies, least prominently in the meat industry, still can use marketing gimmicks to avoid using an "organic" label and still appear as if they are organic.

Also, there is almost no way to absolutely guarantee that an animal has absolutely never come into contact with irregular chemical structures. I understand the importance of antibiotic resistance coupled with herd immunity and overall community health, but the organic industry still isn't at the levels it needs to be to ensure the claims that it's proponents try to make. We are headed in the right direction, but we are still not quite there yet.
author: longliverocknroll5

text:

text: ¬†@Scott Stalmack¬†¬†It's because we also admit we don't know everything and learn and alter our thinking when facts come to light. ¬†Conservatives have a needed answer then twist every new discovery to end up then claiming the Bible had it right all along. ¬†Yes individuals should make an effort but Leo had just spent 3 months in the tar sands. ¬†My life happens to be pretty sweet due to the tar sands. ¬†Canada is just about a petro state. ¬†We need gas...we need to get around but we also need to get this under control within the confines of our lives. ¬†Not having the conversation or saying the problem doesn't exist or focusing on Leo Ferrari's gas milage is not the point. ¬†Their is a problem, 90% of scientists agree. ¬†We are the cause. ¬†Let's just talk about ways we can help ourselves...that's all. ¬†It's about the words coming out of his mouth...not the mouth saying them. text:
VEGANS:¬† Time to weigh in.¬† Leonardo is¬†misinformed.¬† While you American¬†vegans sit there at your computers, you should do a little research on the vegetables you're eating.¬† I'll make it easy.¬† Search GMO.¬† Funny how you think you're saving the planet but all you are really doing is expediting your own demise..¬† If you really want to do something to help, pick from this list

1.A hot water faucet that leaks one drop per second can add up to 165 gallons a month.
That‚Äôs more water than the average person uses in two weeks, plus it has been heated and your water heater will have longer heating cycles.¬† Is your water heated with fossil fuel?¬† Mine is not¬† Texas has hydro-electric facilities for producing clean electricity¬† What kind of fuel do you use to cook your eggplant?¬† We also have plenty of grazing land if you'd like to come graze along side our CATTLE.

2.Every time you open the refrigerator door, up to 30%of the cold air can escape.

3.U.S. energy consumption could be cut by 11% by 2020 through simple building
efficiency measures such as more efficient lighting, water heating, and appliances.

4.If every U.S. home replaced just one light bulb with an ENERGY STAR¬Æ efficient light bulb,
the amount of energy saved could light more than 3 million homes for a year and¬†
PREVENT 9 BILLION POUNDS OF GREENHOUSE GASES PER YEAR, equivalent to the emissions of about 800,000 cars.¬† This Carnivore's house is lighted with LED light bulbs which go far beyond the requirements of Energy Star certification.

5.More than 285,000,000 new computers will be sold this year.¬†
The manufacturing of these machines will require 25 million tons of fossil fuels ‚Äì
more than the whole state of Iowa consumes in 1 year!¬† REDUCE< REUSE< RECYCLE?¬† Hmm...I choose REUSE.¬† I build my own lightning-fast computers
with used components and cabinets (outgrown by gamers)
6.Approximately 30% of energy used in buildings is used inefficiently or unnecessarily.

7.In the average home, 75% of the electricity used to power home electronics is
consumed while the products are TURNED OFF. The average desktop computer idles at 80 watts,¬†¬†Not in my house.¬†
while the average laptop idles at 20 watts.
A Sony PlayStation 3 uses about 200 watts and nearly as much when idle.
Idle power consumes more electricity than is produced by all the solar panels in America combined.¬† 1 switch on my way out the door controls contactors which open, thereby¬†eliminating idle power.¬† Automated systems are commercially available, but hey, don't sweat it.¬† You're a vegan, right?¬† You've done your part.¬† That's good enough ¬†

8.The average home in the U.S. uses about 1,000 kilowatt-hours (kwh) of electricity per month ‚Äì
or the equivalent of: 79 gallons of gas, 18 trees or 29 barbecue grill propane cylinders.¬† 18 trees?¬† Really?¬† How many trees must be cut down to farm your eggplant?¬† If the answer is¬†none, then you're a saint, but my¬†1200 pound steer can graze on 1 acre and provide me with about 500 pounds of trimmed, boneless beef.¬† That's enough¬†to feed me for¬†well over a year

9.The most efficient appliance in your kitchen in your microwave, which uses just 1/3 of the wattage of most ovens.¬† It cooks a mean burger

10.A compact fluorescent bulb (CFL) uses 75% less energy than a traditional incandescent bulb.¬† LED's use less

11.The television sets in the U.S. collectively draw the power equivalent of a
Chernobyl-sized nuclear plant when they are turned OFF! They use this power for
their instant-on capacity, so we don‚Äôt have to wait a minute or two for our screens to warm up.¬† I do not watch television.

Yall have a nice Day(nish).¬† I'm having bacon and eggs>>...
